messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: DIPN: Deep Interaction Prediction Network with Application to Clutter Removal

Paper Abstract: Abstract We propose a Deep Interaction Prediction Network (DIPN) for learning to predict complex interactions that ensue as a robot end-effector pushes multiple objects, whose physical properties, including size, shape, mass, and friction coefficients may be unknown a priori. DIPN “imagines” the effect of a push action and generates an accurate synthetic image of the predicted outcome. DIPN is shown to be sample efficient when trained in simulation or with a real robotic system. The high accuracy of DIPN allows direct integration with a grasp network, yielding a robotic manipulation system capable of executing challenging clutter removal tasks while being trained in a fully self-supervised manner. The overall network demonstrates intelligent behavior in selecting proper actions between push and grasp for completing clutter removal tasks and significantly outperforms the previous state-of-the-art. Remarkably, DIPN achieves even better performance on the real robotic hardware system than in simulation. Videos, code, and experiments log are available at https://github.com/rutgers-arc-lab/dipn.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learning synergies between pushing and grasping with self-supervised deep reinforcement learning",
        "Data-driven grasp synthesis—a survey",
        "Robotic grasping and contact: A review.",
        "PointNetGPD: Detecting grasp configurations from point sets",
        "From caging to grasping",
        "Learning a dictionary of prototypical grasp-predicting parts from grasping experience",
        "Deep learning for detecting robotic grasps",
        "Leveraging big data for grasp planning",
        "Learning 6-dof grasping interaction via deep 3d geometry-aware representations",
        "6-dof graspnet: Variational grasp generation for object manipulation",
        "Using geometry to detect grasp poses in 3d point clouds",
        "Supersizing self-supervision: Learning to grasp from 50k tries and 700 robot hours",
        "Learning deep policies for robot bin picking by simulating robust grasping sequences",
        "Dex-net 2.0: Deep learning to plan robust grasps with synthetic point clouds and analytic grasp metrics",
        "Qt-opt: Scalable deep reinforcement learning for vision-based robotic manipulation",
        "Let’s push things forward: A survey on robot pushing",
        "Estimating the friction parameters of pushed objects",
        "Mechanics and planning of manipulator pushing operations",
        "Stable pushing: Mechanics, controllability, and planning",
        "Dynamic nonprehensile manipulation: Controllability, planning, and experiments",
        "Posing polygonal objects in the plane by pushing",
        "On the scope of quasi-static pushing",
        "Practical force-motion models for sliding manipulation",
        "A Convex Polynomial Force-Motion Model for Planar Sliding: Identification and Application",
        "A convex polynomial model for planar sliding mechanics: theory, application, and experimental validation",
        "Pushing revisited: Differential flatness, trajectory planning, and stabilization",
        "Complexity results and fast methods for optimal tabletop rearrangement with overhand grasps",
        "A framework for push-grasping in clutter",
        "A probabilistic data-driven model for planar pushing",
        "Unsupervised learning for physical interaction through video prediction",
        "Se3-nets: Learning rigid body motion using deep neural networks",
        "Visual interaction networks: Learning a physics simulator from video",
        "On rearrangement of items stored in stacks",
        "Fast, high-quality two-arm rearrangement in synchronous, monotone tabletop setups",
        "Learning contact-rich manipulation skills with guided policy search",
        "End-to-end training of deep visuomotor policies",
        "Deep visual foresight for planning robot motion",
        "Deep predictive policy training using reinforcement learning",
        "Object rearrangement with nested nonprehensile manipulation actions",
        "Towards robust product packing with a minimalistic end-effector",
        "Pre-grasp sliding manipulation of thin objects using soft, compliant, or underactuated hands",
        "Push-grasping with dexterous hands: Mechanics and a method",
        "Object search by manipulation",
        "Physics-Based Grasp Planning Through Clutter",
        "Pregrasp manipulation as trajectory optimization",
        "Learning robot grasping from 3-d images with markov random fields",
        "Efficient optimization for autonomous robotic manipulation of natural objects",
        "Indentification of the center of friction from pushing an object by a mobile robot",
        "Learning to slide unknown objects with differentiable physics simulations",
        "A probabilistic model for planar sliding of objects with unknown material properties: Identification and robust planning",
        "Identifying mechanical models of unknown objects with differentiable physics simulations",
        "Learning to manipulate unknown objects in clutter by reinforcement",
        "Mask r-cnn",
        "Feature pyramid networks for object detection",
        "Learning to see before learning to act: Visual pre-training for manipulation",
        "V-rep: A versatile and scalable robot simulation framework"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in DIPN: Deep Interaction Prediction Network with Application to Clutter Removal, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
